sentences.zh: 昔自在古，歷建正作於孟春。

translations.literal: In ancient times, calendars established the first month to begin in spring.
translations.idiomatic: In ancient times, calendars established the first month to commence in spring.

sentences.zh: 於時冰泮發蟄，百草奮興，秭鳺先滜。

translations.literal: At this season, ice melts and hibernating creatures stir, a hundred plants burst forth vigorously, and the phoenix appears first.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, the ice breaks up and hibernating creatures emerge, the hundred plants flourish vigorously, and the phoenix appears first.

sentences.zh: 物乃歲具，生於東，次順四時，卒于冬分。

translations.literal: All things thus complete their yearly cycle: born in the east, they follow the four seasons in sequence, ending at the winter solstice.
translations.idiomatic: Thus do all things complete their yearly cycle: born in the east, proceeding in order through the four seasons, concluding at the winter solstice.

translations.literal: The cock crows thrice, and then daylight comes.
translations.idiomatic: The cock crows three times, and then light appears.

translations.literal: Following the twelve monthly divisions, it ends at the chou earthly branch.
translations.idiomatic: Following the twelve monthly divisions, it concludes at the chou earthly branch.

translations.literal: Sun and moon achieve completion, hence brightness.
translations.idiomatic: Sun and moon reach fulfillment, therefore brightness.

sentences.zh: 明者孟也，幽者幼也，幽明者雌雄也。

translations.literal: Brightness means primacy, darkness means youth; darkness and brightness are the female and male principles.
translations.idiomatic: The bright means the first, the dark means the young; dark and bright are the female and male principles.

sentences.zh: 雌雄代興，而順至正之統也。

translations.literal: Male and female alternate in ascendancy, thus following the supreme order of correctness.
translations.idiomatic: Male and female alternate in flourishing, thus following the supreme correct principle.

translations.literal: Sun returns to the west, rises bright in the east;
translations.idiomatic: The sun returns to the west, rises brightly in the east;

translations.literal: the moon sets in the east, rising brightly in the west.
translations.idiomatic: the moon returns to the east, rises brightly in the west.

sentences.zh: 正不率天，又不由人，則凡事易壞而難成矣。

translations.literal: If the calendar neither follows heaven nor is established by human convention, then all undertakings easily fail and are difficult to accomplish.
translations.idiomatic: If the calendar does not follow heaven nor is established by man, then all affairs easily spoil and are hard to accomplish.

sentences.zh: 王者易姓受命，必慎始初，改正朔，易服色，推本天元，順承厥意。

translations.literal: When kings change surname and receive the mandate, they must be careful at the beginning, change the first day of the month, change clothing colors, trace back to heaven's origin, follow and receive its intent.
translations.idiomatic: When kings change their clan name and receive the mandate, they must be careful at the outset: change the beginning of the month, alter the colors of clothing, trace back to heaven's primal origin, and follow its intentions.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：神農以前尚矣。

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: "From the time of Shennong and earlier, it is too ancient."
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: "From the time of Shennong and earlier, it is exceedingly ancient."

sentences.zh: 蓋黃帝考定星歷，建立五行，起消息，正閏餘，於是有天地神祇物類之官，是謂五官。

translations.literal: Indeed, the Yellow Emperor examined and fixed the stars and calendar, established the five elements, began the alternation of yin and yang, rectified the intercalary months, and thus there were the officials of heaven, gods, things, and classes—this is called the five officials.
translations.idiomatic: Indeed, the Yellow Emperor examined and established the stars and calendar, set up the five elements, began the alternation of yin and yang, corrected the intercalary months, and thus there were the officials of heaven, spirits, things, and classes—this is called the five officials.

translations.literal: The people and spirits have different functions, yet they respect each other without violating each other, thus the spirits send down auspicious births, and the people honor them with offerings—calamities do not arise, and what is sought does not run short.
translations.idiomatic: People and spirits have different occupations, yet they respect each other without violating each other, thus spirits send down auspicious offspring, and people honor them with offerings—calamities do not arise, and what is sought does not come up short.

sentences.zh: 民是以能有信，神是以能有明德。

translations.literal: In the decline of the Shaohao clan, the nine Li caused moral decay; the people and spirits became mixed and disturbed, unable to regulate things—calamities multiplied, and they could not exhaust their vital energy.
translations.idiomatic: In the decline of the Shaohao clan, the nine Li caused virtue to decay; people and spirits became mixed and disturbed, unable to govern things—calamities multiplied, and they could not exhaust their vital energy.

sentences.zh: 民神異業，敬而不瀆，故神降之嘉生，民以物享，災禍不生，所求不匱。

translations.literal: Zhuanxu received this, and commanded Chong to assist heaven, and Li to assist earth, so that they would restore the old customs without encroaching or violating each other.
translations.idiomatic: Zhuanxu received this, and commanded Chong to assist heaven, and Li to assist earth, so they would restore the old ways without mutually violating each other.

sentences.zh: 少暤氏之衰也，九黎亂德，民神雜擾，不可放物，禍菑薦至，莫盡其氣。

translations.literal: The people and spirits became distinct in their functions, respected each other without violating each other, thus the spirits sent down auspicious births, and the people honored them with offerings—calamities did not arise, and what is sought did not run short.
translations.idiomatic: People and spirits became distinct in their occupations, respected each other without violating each other, thus spirits sent down auspicious offspring, and people honored them with offerings—calamities did not arise, and what was sought did not come up short.

sentences.zh: 顓頊受之，乃命南正重司天以屬神，命火正黎司地以屬民，使復舊常，無相侵瀆。

translations.literal: The way of the gods is honored, the way of the people is valued—thus the people are diligent in goodness, and the spirits are honored.
translations.idiomatic: The way of the spirits is honored, the way of the people is valued—thus the people are diligent in goodness, and the spirits are honored.

sentences.zh: 其後三苗服九黎之德，故二官咸廢所職，而閏餘乖次，孟陬殄滅，攝提無紀，歷數失序。

translations.literal: The Grand Historian says: "When the calendar is correct, yin and yang are regulated, wind and rain are timely, vital energy arrives, and the people have no premature deaths or epidemics.
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: "When the calendar is correct, yin and yang are regulated, wind and rain are timely, vital energy arrives, and the people suffer no premature deaths or epidemics.

sentences.zh: 堯復遂重黎之後，不忘舊者，使復典之，而立羲和之官。

translations.literal: When the seasons are clear and the degrees are correct, yin and yang are balanced, wind and rain are timely, vital energy arrives, and the people have no premature deaths or epidemics.
translations.idiomatic: When the seasons are clear and the divisions are correct, yin and yang are balanced, wind and rain are timely, vital energy arrives, and the people suffer no premature deaths or epidemics.

sentences.zh: 明時正度，則陰陽調，風雨節，茂氣至，民無夭疫。

translations.literal: If the calendar is not followed, then yin and yang are disordered, wind and rain are untimely, vital energy does not arrive, and the people suffer premature deaths and epidemics.
translations.idiomatic: If the calendar is not followed, then yin and yang become disordered, wind and rain are untimely, vital energy does not arrive, and the people suffer premature deaths and epidemics.

translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: "The calendar must accord with heaven and earth.

translations.literal: If it accords with heaven and earth, then the people prosper.
translations.idiomatic: If it accords with heaven and earth, then the people prosper.

sentences.zh: 先王之正時也，履端於始，舉正於中，歸邪於終。

translations.literal: If it does not accord with heaven and earth, then the people suffer.
translations.idiomatic: If it does not accord with heaven and earth, then the people suffer.

translations.literal: Therefore the sage kings were careful about the calendar.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore the sage kings were careful about the calendar.

translations.idiomatic: They observed the sun, moon, and stars.

translations.idiomatic: They calculated the seasons and divisions.

sentences.zh: 其後戰國并爭，在於彊國禽敵，救急解紛而已，豈遑念斯哉！

translations.literal: Thus the calendar was established correctly.
translations.idiomatic: Thus the calendar was established correctly.

sentences.zh: 是時獨有鄒衍，明於五德之傳，而散消息之分，以顯諸侯。

translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: "In the time of Emperor Wu of Han.

translations.idiomatic: The calendar was reformed.

translations.idiomatic: The pitch pipes were tuned.

translations.idiomatic: The sacrifices were performed.

translations.literal: Thus the way of heaven and earth was followed.
translations.idiomatic: Thus the way of heaven and earth was followed.

sentences.zh: 雖明習歷及張蒼等，咸以為然。

translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: "The calendar is the foundation of the state.

sentences.zh: 是時天下初定，方綱紀大基，高后女主，皆未遑，故襲秦正朔服色。

translations.idiomatic: If the calendar is correct, the state prospers.

translations.idiomatic: They did not dare to be careless.

translations.idiomatic: Thus their states endured.

translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: "I have written this treatise on the calendar.

translations.literal: I hope that future rulers will follow it.
translations.idiomatic: I hope that future rulers will follow it.

translations.idiomatic: Thus the state will be well governed.

translations.literal: Now, the Yellow Emperor ordered Xi and He to respectfully receive the gods of heaven, to follow the seasons and months, to establish the first day of the month, to fix the positions of the sun and moon, to determine yin and yang, to harmonize the four seasons, to adjust the five elements, to harmonize the twelve pitch pipes, to regulate the calendar, to rectify the sacrifices, and to unify the measures—all these were the offices of Xi and He.

translations.idiomatic: The Shang preserved it.

translations.idiomatic: Thus civilization was established.
